Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX 2014-2015 TREATMENT
DisplayText: Early treatment as alternative to chemoprophylaxis

Contents.Text: Early treatment as alternative to chemoprophylaxis:
In most cases, if a person is suspected of having been exposed to
influenza, early treatment should signs or symptoms develop is preferred
The provider should explain the early signs and symptoms of influenza
to the patient and advise the patient to immediately contact a health
care provider for evaluation and possible early treatment if these
symptoms or signs develop. Influenza-like symptoms or signs include
fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache,
chills, fatigue, vomiting, and diarrhea. Influenza can present without
Health care providers should use clinical judgement regarding situations
where early recognition of illness and treatment might be an appropriate
Early treatment alternative or chemoprophylaxis may be considered for:
*Persons who are part of a high-risk group and are household or close
contacts of someone with influenza-like illness
*Health care personnel who have occupational exposures
*Resident of a long term care facility that had close contact with
another resident or staff with influenza-like illness.
*Atypical situations (such as case clusters). Contact Minnesota
Department of Health for consultation. Telephone number:
Duration of antiviral treatment is 10 days. Among long-term care
residents, the antiviral use should be re-evaluated after 10 days.
If no further exposures have occurred, antivirals should be discontinued.

Decide whether a likely pathogen has been identified from respiratory secretions
or blood. The clinician must decide whether any organisms identified on smear
or culture of respiratory tract secretions reflect disease, colonization, or

The quality of a respiratory secretion sample must be evaluated. Sputum sample
with fewer than 25 polymorphonuclear leukocytes per high power field (hpf) are
unlikely to be from a site of bacterial infection unless the patient is
profoundly neutropenic. Sputum samples with more than 10 epithelial cells/hp
are likely to be contaminated with upper respiratory tract secretions.
In cases of bacterial pneumonia, a gram stain of a high quality respiratory

Step 3. Adjust or discontinue antimicrobial therapy

If the patient does not have convincing evidence for bacterial pneumonia and/

Contents.Text: ABOUT THE ANTIMICROBIAL COMPUTERIZED DECISION SUPPORT SYSTEM (CDSS)
The Antimicrobial CDSS is a tool within the Computerized Patient Record System
that offers antimicrobial prescribing advice to clinicians at the point of order
entry. The system is structured as an order menu decision tree that contains
quick orders pre-programmed with appropriate antimicrobial regimens for specific
Improve patient outcomes, reduce rates of microbial resistance, prevent adverse
patient outcomes, optimize costs and improve providers' lives. In addition to
these goals, the program fulfills antimicrobial stewardship quality standards
In a 2013 study, Minneapolis Veterans Affairs Medical Center (MVAMC)
antimicrobial courses ordered through the Antimicrobial CDSS were significantly
more likely to be appropriate from start to completion, (44%) compared to non-
CDSS courses (33%, P = 0.013). This is consistent with other studies that have
shown significant improvement in appropriate use of antimicrobials when CDSS
The Minneapolis VAHCS has a restricted antimicrobial formulary. A restricted
formulary reduces cost of health care and is an integral part of antimicrobial
stewardship. The Antimicrobial CDSS provides a method of formulary restriction
that doesn't require a call back from pharmacy or a prior authorization for the
Along with being able to order restricted antimicrobials without a prior
authorization or call back from pharmacy, the Antimicrobial CDSS provides quick
orders pre-programmed with appropriate antimicrobial regimens for specific
infectious diseases. Using the system saves time and increases the efficiency of
The CDSS has been developed locally with input from a broad, representative
group of clinicians. Recommendations have been based on local susceptibility
patterns, clinical evidence, local preferences, and national guidelines. The
CDSS provides a way for clinicians to select alternative drugs when the
Detailed instructions can be found in the link below.

Contents.Text: Medication orders placed using the CDSS system will NOT require Infectious
Disease approval.  Because prescribing advice within the system has been
developed with input from a broad, representative group of clinicians and the
recommendations that have emerged are  based on site-specific susceptibility
patterns, clinical evidence, local preferences, and national guidelines,
INFECTIOUS DISEASE APPROVAL FOR RESTRICTED ANTIMICROBIALS WILL NOT BE NEEDED at
participating VA sites.  Clinicians are still encouraged to seek advice from
Infectious Diseases whenever it would be helpful.

Contents.Text: Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole 1 DS tablet q12h ($) [R,DI] for 14 days
Acute bacterial prostatitis typically presents with fever, dysuria, chills,
malaise, myalgia, pelvic or perianal pain. On exam, the prostate gland is tense,
boggy, and extremely tender. The urinalysis reveals pyuria, and the urine
culture is positive. Men with dysuria and fever but without pyuria and/or
bacteriuria should be seen by a urologist. If there is any suspicion of abscess,
especially in men older than 40 years, the patient should be seen by a urologist
and transurethral prostate resection for drainage should be considered.
Most cases in men aged 35 and older, those with recent urinary tract
instrumentation or surgery (e.g., prostate biopsy, vasectomy) are associated
with enteric Gram-negative rods. Most cases in men under age 35 and those who
are at high risk of sexually transmitted infections are associated with N.
gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis. Resistant organisms are more likely if the
patient has been in the hospital for more than 48 hours or received a course of
antibiotics. There is increasing resistance in urinary pathogens to
A urine Gram stain and culture should be performed in all patients to guide
There is limited data on duration of antimicrobial treatment for prostatitis. 14
days minimum is required. 4 to 6 weeks may be necessary to completely eradicate
bacteria in the prostate to ensure patient does not progress to chronic
Hydration, bed rest and analgesics are recommended along with antimicrobials
Age < 35 years and those at high risk of sexually transmitted infections
Lipsky et al., Clinical Infectious Diseases, 2010, 50(12)1641-1652
Mandell chapter: Prostatitis, Epididymitis and Orchitis

Contents.Text: The decision to treat should be based on clinical symptoms and/or presence of
a high risk condition, and should NOT be delayed until laboratory test
It is important to use antiviral drugs early to treat influenza in people who
are very sick with influenza (for example hospitalized people) and people who
are sick with influenza and have a greater chance of getting severe
complications. If a patient is not in a high-risk group or is not hospitalized,
healthcare providers should use clinical judgment to guide treatment decisions.
People who have a greater chance of serious influenza complications include:
*Persons who have chronic pulmonary (including asthma) or cardiovascular
(except isolated hypertension), renal, hepatic, hematologic, metabolic
*Persons who are immunocompromised due to any cause (including immunosuppresion
caused by medications or by HIV infection)
*Persons younger than 19 years of age who are receiving long-term aspirin-
or salicylate-containing medications and who might be at risk for experiencing
Reye syndrome after influenza virus infection
*Residents of nursing homes and other long-term care facilities
*Persons who are extremely obese (BMI greater than or equal to 40)
If indicated, antivirals should be started as soon as possible.  Maximal
benefit occurs when started within 48 hours of symptom onset.  However,
antivirals should not be withheld if symptoms began more than 48 hours prior
and the patient meets criteria for treatment and remains severely ill.
Extending the duration of treatment for oseltamivir may be needed
for those patients with prolonged illness or who are immunosuppressed.
*Pregnant women and women up to 2 weeks after the end of pregnancy

Contents.Text: Bacteremia usually results from a focal infection somewhere in the body. If a
focal infection is not obvious, a careful search should be made beginning with a
If a focal infection seems to be the source of the bacteremia, select
antimicrobials active against pathogens likely to be present in the focal
infection. Return to the main menu and select the relevant diagnosis or
For infections with signs and/or symptoms of severe sepsis, like hypotension or
Obtain blood cultures before starting antibiotics when signs or symptoms suggest
bacteremia. Obtain 2 or 3 blood culture sets from different venipuncture sites
within a 24 hour period. When suspicion is strong and the patient's signs and
symptoms have not responded, obtain 2 blood culture sets the next day. For more
information about blood cultures, see recommendations on the Q-drive
Q:\MICROBIOL INFO FOR CLINICIANS\BLOOD CULTURE Recommendations.doc
Empirical treatment of suspected bacteremia if local infection is not apparent
and blood cultures are not yet positive
Cultures usually become positive after 1 or more days. Usually interim results
are reported first, followed by final identification and sensitivities after
another day or two. Adjust antimicrobials as appropriate as this sequence
Preliminary results of a positive culture are available
When a focal infection is not apparent, the type of bacteria growing in blood
culture might suggest a focal infection and direct the search for a diagnosis.
When a focal infection is apparent, it may suggest the identity of the bacteria
growing in blood cultures before the laboratory completes its identification.
Preliminary positive results should lead to changes in antimicrobial therapy to
target suspected pathogens, narrow the spectrum, reduce toxicity, and reduce

These cultures should be drawn at different times with the first and last

For a patient who is not clinically stable, or if the progression of the illness

Ascertain whether any antimicrobials were taken during the previous 2 weeks to
Penicillin susceptibility data are used to determine appropriate antimicrobial
therapy for streptococcal endocarditis. Because bacteria in cardiac vegetations
are not actively dividing, and are protected from host defense mechanisms,
bactericidal antimicrobial regimens are necessary to treat bacterial
endocarditis. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cut-off levels used to
select therapy for endocarditis differ from those used to select therapy for
Beta-lactam antibiotics are more effective than vancomycin for treating
susceptible gram-positive pathogens. For patients with penicillin allergy that
is known or suspected to be class I (anaphylaxis, angioedema, or hives),
penicillin desensitization or therapy with a cephalosporin is usually the best
When gentamicin is used for synergy against gram positive bacteria, serum
concentrations should be 3-4 mcg/ml peak and < 1 mcg/ml trough. Once daily
gentamicin dosing can be used for streptococcal cases but not for staphylococcal

Contents.DisplayText: Bacterial meningitis with E. Coli, Pseudomonas, or other organism
Contents.Text: E. Coli, Pseudomonas, or another organism
Meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges and tissues surrounding the brain
and spinal cord. It is characterized by an abnormal amount of white blood cells
in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and symptoms include headache, fever, mental
status changes, nuchal rigidity, and nausea.
The sudden onset of meningeal symptoms within hours to days caused by several
infectious etiologies, including bacterial, viral, fungal and protozoa, as well
as non-infectious etiologies. Bacterial meningitis is the most common type of
meningitis, accounting for up to 90% of cases where a CSF culture was obtained
prior to starting antimicrobials. Non-bacterial meningitis is commonly referred
to as aseptic meningitis (refer to "Negative CSF culture" below for
Patients with acute bacterial meningitis often have severe symptoms and present
soon after onset of infection. The relationship between predisposing factors and
common bacterial pathogen are listed below.
Predisposing Factors and Common Bacterial Pathogens
*Age > 50 years - S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, L. monocytogenes, aerobic
*Immunocompromised state - S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, L. monocytogenes,
*Basilar skull fracture - S. pneumoniae: H. influenzae, group A and
*Head trauma: after neurosurgery - Staphylococcus aureus, coagulase-negative
Initial Management of Suspected Acute Bacterial Meningitis
Once a diagnosis of acute bacterial meningitis is considered likely,
antimicrobials should be initiated as soon as possible after obtaining blood
cultures and performing a lumbar puncture (LP) to obtain CSF. Two blood cultures
should be drawn based on predisposing factors above. LP should be performed in
nearly all patients to obtain CSF for establishing diagnosis and determining
infectious organism/susceptibility. Computed tomography (CT) should be performed
prior to LP in some patients (see list below). If CT must be obtained prior to
LP or there is another delay in performing LP, empiric antimicrobials should not
be delayed and initiated immediately after obtaining blood cultures only.
Relative LP contraindications (no absolute contraindications exist):
Anticoagulation therapy or bleeding disorder, spinal epidural abscess, raised
Computed tomography scan should be performed prior to lumbar puncture in cases
with the following: Immunocompromise, history of CNS disease, new onset seizure,
papilledema, abnormal level of consciousness, focal neurologic deficit.
LP opening pressure is often elevated in bacterial meningitis. CSF findings
characteristic of bacterial meningitis include CSF glucose <40mg/dL, CSF to
serum glucose ratio </=0.4, CSF protein concentration >/=200 mg/dL and CSF WBC
Empiric Treatment After Blood Cultures are Drawn, and CSF is Obtained, or if LP
Empiric Treatment Based on CSF Gram-Stain Results
When gram stain results are available, adjust antimicrobials to optimize therapy
Treatment Based on CSF Isolated Organism
When infectious organism is identified, adjust antimicrobials to optimize therap
Patients who have a negative CSF culture, but have symptoms and CSF findings
consistent with bacterial meningitis should be treated based on likely pathogen.
Patients with negative CSF culture, symptoms of acute meningitis but have labs
inconsistent with bacterial meningitis should be considered to have aseptic
meningitis. Aseptic meningitis is caused by a variety of non-bacterial
infectious etiologies and non-infectious etiologies. Consult Infectious Disease
Sanford keyword: Meningitis, bacterial, positive gram stain
Tunkel et al., Clin Infect Dis, 2004, 39.1267-84

ORZID2 GMENU UROSEPSIS
Contents.Text: Bacteremia or sepsis with urinary tract source (aka urosepsis)
Urinary tract infections (UTI) occur in patients with symptoms of infection in
the lower urinary tract (cystitis) and/or the upper urinary tract
(pyelonephritis). Cystitis refers to infection of the urinary bladder, but
inflammation often extends into the urethra. Typical signs and symptoms include
dysuria, increased urinary frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.
Uncomplicated cystitis occurs in people with structurally and neurogenically
normal urinary tract. Most cases of uncomplicated cystitis occur in
pre-menopausal, non-pregnant, sexually active young women and is associated with
Enterobacteriaceae (e.g. E. coli and Klebsiella sp.) and occasionally S.
saprophyticus. Complicated cystitis occurs in the conditions listed below and is
associated with Enterobacteriaceae, but more resistant pathogens occur,
including the Gram-positive pathogens staphylococci and enterococci. Features of
pyelonephritis include fever/other signs of systemic infection, flank pain,
costovertebral tenderness, and pelvic or perianal pain in men. In rare and
severe cases, urinary tract infections can also present with bacteremia, sepsis,
multiple organ system dysfunction, shock and/or acute renal failure.
When a patient presents with symptoms of cystitis, like dysuria, increased
frequency, and suprapubic pain, perform a urine culture. Antimicrobial therapy
is not indicated for pyuria in the absence of symptoms. Patients with signs and
symptoms of pyelonephritis should have a urinary culture and susceptibility
obtained and a urine Gram-stain performed prior to starting empirical
antimicrobials to guide therapy. Patients presenting with bacteremia, sepsis,
multiorgan dysfunction, shock and/or acute renal failure should be treated
accordingly with urinary tract as the foci of infection.
Asymptomatic bacteriuria occurs in patients who have bacteria in the urine but
do not have symptoms of a urinary tract infection. Asymptomatic bacteriuria is

Antimicrobials have no role for treatment of aspiration and their use entails

Contents.Text: CDI: Patient with clinical symptom onset (e.g., 3 or more unformed stools in
24 hours after discontinuation of laxatives) and laboratory confirmation of CDI.
CDI Recurrence: Typically defined as a repeated symptomatic, laboratory
case of CDI within 12 weeks after a prior episode.
Discontinue implicated antibiotic and avoid high risk antibiotic if antibiotic
therapy is still needed. Discontinue laxatives. Reassess need for tube feeds. C.
difficile PCR testing should be completed to confirm diagnosis of C. difficile
Medium: carbapenems, penicillins, 1st generation cephalosporins, macrolides,
Very low: sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin, fosfomycin, methenamine
Avoid antiperistaltic agents (narcotics, loperamide, etc.). Increasing evidence
suggests that antacid therapy, especially with PPIs and H2 blockers, increases
the risk for C. difficile disease and recurrences. Avoid antacid therapy
without clear indication, especially in patients at risk for primary recurrent C
The preferred route of antimicrobial therapy for C. difficile infection is by
mouth. Intravenous metronidazole should be used only when oral therapy cannot
be used to deliver drug to the colon. Intravenous vancomycin does not get into
colonic contents and is not effective.
C. difficile infection usually responds to antimicrobial therapy, especially if
other antimicrobial therapy has been stopped. Relapse is usually due to failure
of normal colonic flora to re-establish itself, rather than antimicrobial
treatment failure. If symptoms do not respond to appropriate antimicrobial
therapy, re-consider the diagnosis. Relapse occurs in 6% to 25% of people after
their first episode of C. difficile infection.
Third Recurrence: Consult Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Disease

Patients who have no symptoms of cystitis (i.e., no dysuria, pain, urgency)

Bacteriuria in pregnant women is associated with pyelonephritis, premature
delivery, and lower birth weight. Screening for bacteriuria is recommended at
least once early in pregnancy. If bacteriuria is not found upon initial testing,
further screening cultures are not needed. If bacteriuria (>10,000 CFU/mL) is
present, the patient should be treated. Testing should be repeated throughout

Balanitis is inflammation of the glans penis and is often associated with
erythema and pruritis. When the foreskin is also involved, the condition is
known as balanoposthitis (also referred to as balanitis in this discussion).
There are a variety of causes of balanitis, but most are due to poor hygiene of
the foreskin in uncircumcised men resulting in candida infection. Other, less
common causes, include bacterial infection (typically sexually transmitted or
anaerobic bacteria), dermatologic conditions, malignancy as well as others. Men
with Candidal balanitis often have a white curd-like exudate compared to a thick
foul-smelling purulent exudate in menu with anaerobic bacterial balanitis.

Contents.Text: Acute bronchitis should not be treated with antimicrobials except in specific
circumstances. If pneumonia is suspected, order a chest x-ray.  If an
infiltrate is not present, the patient does not have bacterial pneumonia and
need not be treated for it.
Acute bronchitis in an otherwise HEALTHY PATIENT
Antimicrobials provide no benefit.  If bronchitis persists beyond 2 weeks,
additional diagnostic workup is needed to find a cause.  If a patient has
persistent cough with inspiratory whoop, consider a diagnosis of pertussis.
Acute bronchitis in patients with COPD
Symptoms of COPD exacerbation include dyspnea with increased sputum purulence
and volume, together with increased cough and wheeze. Co-morbidities are
common in COPD patients, thus exacerbations must be differentiated clinically
from other events such as acute coronary syndrome, worsening heart failure,
Cornerstones of therapy include oxygen, bronchodilators, and in some cases
corticosteroids. Recommend antibiotics for moderately or severely ill patients
with COPD exacerbation who have increased sputum purulence and volume.
NOTE: Fluoroquinolones are not listed as a choice because the risk of serious

Acute bronchitis is a clinical syndrome with a brief, self-limited
pneumonia on chest radiograph. It is accompanied by dry or productive cough
lasting up to 3 weeks, is most prevalent in winter, and is primarily caused
by viruses.More than 1 in 20 people have acute bronchitis per year, with
highest rates during the winter months.  This discussion does not pertain to
acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis, a clinical syndrome also
frequently associated with viral infection, but in which bacteria play a more
decongestants, and beta 2-agonists have been used to treat patients with
acute bronchitis, but controlled trials have not clearly concluded that they
Empirical antibacterial therapy has repeatedly been shown to provide no
benefit for most patients.  Acute bronchitis remains one of the five most
frequently cited rationales for excessive antibiotic use in outpatients.
Acute bronchitis and other acute respiratory syndromes (otitis media,
sinusitis, pharyngitis, upper respiratory infections) account for
approximately 75% of ambulatory prescriptions in the United States.  Current
guidelines, endorsed by a number of national societies, including the
Infectious Diseases Society of America, do not recommend the routine use of
antibiotics for uncomplicated acute bronchitis in otherwise normal persons.
If pertussis is suspected, early therapy with macrolides or
tetracyclines is indicated to prevent transmission, although the clinical
findings early in pertussis infection are indistinguishable from viral causes
of bronchitis, and the incidence of disease is very low.  Treat for pertussis
only when a patient has likely been exposed to other cases.
Asthma attacks often have symptoms resembling bronchitis.  Asthma
attacks do not benefit from antimicrobial therapy.

Asymptomatic candiduria in a patient with a urinary catheter should not be

Candida vulvovaginitis typically presents with valvular irritation, burning or
pruritus. Vaginal pH should be measured, and the specimen should be examined
under the microscope for clue cells (epithelial cell coated with bacteria) to
exclude bacterial vaginosis. In candida vulvovaginitis, the vaginal pH is
typically normal (4-4.5) and vaginal discharge is typically thick and curdy with
white plaques on vaginal mucosa. Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying fungus or
Most non-C. albicans species respond to fluconazole treatment except C. krusei
and C. glabrata. C. krusei can be treated with topical agents as for complicated
candida vulvovaginitis below. C. glabrata treatment is complicated and azole
therapy is frequently unsuccessful. Consult Infectious Diseases in patients with
Recurrent candida vulvovaginitis is treated as complicated candida
vulvovaginitis for induction treatment, followed by maintenance regimen for 6
Treatment of complicated candida vulvovaginitis (e.g. immunocompromised, severe
disease, pregnancy) or recurrent infection induction treatment
Recurrent candida vulvovaginitis maintenance regimen following induction
Failure of azole therapy is common, alternative topical treatments below require
compounding by a pharmacist. Please call pharmacy to order.

for vancomycin).  Other factors to consider are the drug-drug interactions

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX REFERENCES

Contents.Text: Cellulitis refers to inflammation of the skin and subcutaneous tissue and is
often associated with bacterial pathogens.  The most common pathogens are group
A streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus.  Group B streptococci are associated
with cellulitis in elderly people, in those with diabetes mellitus, and on feet
and legs of patients with athlete's foot (tinea pedis).
Mild cases can be treated with oral antimicrobials.  Moderate to severe cases
should be treated initially with intravenous antimicrobials.  Switch to oral
Consider MRSA coverage for cellulitis associated with penetrating trauma, a
history of MRSA infection, injection drug use, or infections not responding
Duration: Treat for 5 days. Re-evaluate the patient and extend/modify treatment
if not improved in this time.
Mild: Cellulitis without systemic signs of infection
Alternative for Penicillin Allergy or MRSA suspected
Moderate: Cellulitis with systemic signs of infection
Alternative for penicillin allergy or MRSA suspected
Severe: Cellulitis in patients with signs of deeper infections
(e.g. bullae, skin sloughing, hypotension, or evidence of organ dysfunction).
Patients may also qualify as severe if they are neutropenic, have a
hematologic malignancy or congenital immunodeficiency, or are receiving
immunosuppressant therapy.  Consider whether surgical drainage is necessary.
Alternative for penicillin allergy or MRSA suspected:
Mandell chapter: Cellulitis and subcutaneous tissue infections

CHRONIC PROSTATITIS / CHRONIC PELVIC PAIN SYNDROME
This syndrome presents with intermittent perineal and/or low back pain,
obstructive voiding symptoms, relatively normal examination, and negative urine
cultures. Antimicrobial therapy is not indicated.
Consult urology for non-antimicrobial therapy recommendations (e.g.
alpha-adrenergic antagonists, anti-inflammatory medications) to reduce symptoms.

Chronic bacterial prostatitis usually presents as recurrent urinary tract
infections with the same bacterial etiology. Pain, tenderness, and fever may
accompany intermittent episodes of cystitis, but men are usually asymptomatic
between episodes and the prostate examination may be normal. Non-steroidal anti-
inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) often relieve pain. If the diagnosis is uncertain or
if the patient's symptoms do not respond to therapy, consult urology. The
presence of hematuria may be a sign of carcinoma, especially in older men, and a
A urine culture should be performed in all patients to guide antimicrobial
Chronic prostate pain syndrome should be considered in patients who have
symptoms of prostatitis but have negative urine cultures. Chronic prostate pain
4 weeks minimum and up to 6 weeks of treatment is required. Durations longer
than 6 weeks may be needed in treatment of resistant organisms. Treatment with
trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole requires a treatment duration of 1 to 3 months.
Lipsky et al., Clinical Infectious Diseases, 2010, 50(12)1641-1652

Contents.Text: COLONIZED RESPIRATORY TRACT IN A PATIENT ON A VENTILATOR
The respiratory tracts of persons who are intubated, have a
tracheostomy, or have other abnormalities of the larynx or trachea are
usually colonized with bacteria and often fungi. The bacteria can be of
relatively low virulence (e.g. coagulase negative staphylococci, streptococci,
candida) or of potentially greater virulence (Staphylococcus aureus,
enterobacteriaceae, pseudomonas). Candida and enterococci are common
respiratory tract colonizers and they almost never cause pneumonia. There is
no benefit from treatment of patients with systemic antimicrobials simply
because the respiratory tract is colonized with a potential pathogen and there
is no evidence of an infiltrate. Systemic antimicrobial therapy will select for
resistant organisms and may lead to other adverse effects.
See below for ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment recommendations in
patients with a new or progressive infiltrate and at least one of the following:
fever greater than 100.4F, leukocytosis, leukopenia or purulent bronchial
Kalil et al. Clin Infect Dis, 2016, 63(5): e61-e111.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX COLONIZED WOUNDS

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU DECUBITUS ULCERS
ORZID2 GMENU FOOT ULCER WITH DM
Contents.DisplayText: Foot ulcer in patient with diabetes mellitus

Contents.Text: Open wounds are usually colonized with bacteria and often fungi. This is true of
ulcers (see below), post-operative wounds, traumatic wounds, and others. Then
bacteria can be of relatively low virulence (eg, coagulase negative
staphylococci, diphtheroids) or of potentially greater virulence (Staphylococcus
aureus, enterobacteriaceae, pseudomonas). Candida is commonly present on wounds
that are moist or covered. There is no need to treat patients with systemic
antimicrobials simply because a wound culture is positive for a potential
pathogen. Topical antimicrobials are not effective in nearly all circumstances
and can select for resistant organisms or lead to other adverse effects.
Systemic antimicrobial therapy may be indicated if there are signs of infection.
Lipsky et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2012, 54(12): e132-e173
Up-to-Date article: Clinical assessment of chronic wounds

Contents.Text: Stepdown empiric treatment for CAP with oral antibiotics
Empirical regimens listed here cover the usual pathogens associated with CAP,
including atypical pathogens.  Specific therapy should be guided by culture
CAP Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) or PORT Score
The CAP pneumonia severity index is useful for estimation of mortality risk for
a patient with pneumonia.  Pre-estimated risk can then be used to determine how
aggressively to treat the patient's pneumonia and whether the patient can be
treated safely outside of the hospital.
The Community-Acquired Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) is a guide and
should be used to augment clinical judgment. If social circumstances
or cognitive dysfunction would interfere with success of outpatient
treatment, the patient should be hospitalized.
If a patient has taken an antimicrobial in the previous 3 months, it is prudent
to avoid giving the same or a similar drug for the current episode of pneumonia.

Contents.Text: GUIDELINES FOR PREVENTION OF POST-OPERATIVE SKIN INFECTIONS
Most dermatologic surgeries involve "clean" sites that are unlikely to develop
post-operative infections. Antibiotics are not recommended in these cases
because the risks of antibiotic adverse events outweigh potential benefits. In
general, antibiotics are used to prevent post-operative wound infection
For background information on surgical prophylaxis in dermatological surgery:
For specific recommendations on surgical prophylaxis in dermatological surgery:
Antibiotics are used to prevent endocarditis that might result from a surgical
procedure, but the benefits are theoretical, not evidence-based, and there is
general agreement that benefits outweigh antibiotic risks only when the risk of
endocarditis is high and the surgical procedure is likely to result in
bacteremia. For dermatological surgery, antibiotics to prevent endocarditis
should be considered for surgery on mucosal sites, groin sites, or an inflamed
or infected site. For more on prevention of endocarditis and drug
For information and drug recommendations on management of cases of infection

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX DUKE CRITERIA

Contents.Text: Diagnosis and management are complex. Cardiology, Infectious Disease, and
Surgery services should all be involved in diagnosis and management of infective
Endocarditis is the result of growth of microorganisms on endothelium of the
heart. The integrity of the endothelial surface must be compromised in order to
allow microorganisms to attach and proliferate. Often such lesions are caused by
abnormal blood flow or thrombi resulting from heart valvular disease, prosthetic
heart valves, or from foreign material or microorganisms introduced to the
bloodstream as byproducts of illicit intravenous drug use.
Endocarditis should be considered a possible diagnosis in a patient with
persistent bacteremia without an identifiable focal infection, especially when
the patient has a structural heart abnormality, prosthesis, or has a recent
history of intravenous illicit drug use.
Diagnosis of endocarditis can be based on several combinations of signs and
symptoms. The Duke criteria help categorize cases as definite or possible
endocarditis based on major and minor criteria. The Duke criteria also indicate
when a diagnosis of endocarditis can be excluded.
Endocarditis is categorized by time course and severity of symptoms of illness
into acute and subacute. These classifications help suggest which pathogens may
be more likely associated with symptoms.
Acute endocarditis is a rapidly progressing illness that often causes fever. It
can be associated with spread of infection to other parts of the body and can
cause death within a matter of weeks. In patient with suspected acute
endocarditis, three sets of blood cultures should be obtained with the first and
last cultures separated by at least one hour. Empiric antimicrobial therapy
should then be initiated as soon as possible.
Subacute endocarditis follows an indolent course. Generally, patients have had
some symptoms for at least 2 weeks. Symptoms are more subtle and spread of
infection to other systems is uncommon. In patients with suspected subacute
endocarditis, every attempt should be made to identify a pathogen prior to
initiating antimicrobial therapy. These patients should be observed carefully
for signs of heart failure or embolic complications, and if signs are noted,
Mandell chapter: Endocarditis and intravascular infections

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX DRUG ALLERGIES

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX PENICILLIN DESENS PROTOCOL

Contents.Text: The nature and circumstances of a possible previous reaction including the
timing should be considered. In many cases, previous reactions are clearly
*Immediate - within one hour of starting drug administration.
Type I reactions present with urticaria, hypotension, angioedema, bronchospasm,
or anaphylaxis and occur within an hour of exposure. These reactions are
immunoglobulin E (IgE) and mast cell and/or basophil mediated.
*Delayed - After one hour of starting administration (usually after 6 days)
1) Type II reactions manifest as hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and
neutropenia. They are caused by antibody (usually IgG)- mediated cell
2) Type III reactions can manifest as serum sickness, vasculitis or Arthus
reaction, and are caused by IgG:drug immune complex deposition and complement
3) Type IV reactions typically manifest as contact dermatitis, morbilliform
epidermal necrolysis) and other presentations. They are T-cell mediated.
Repeated exposures lead to reactions that are of the same type.
Approximately 10% of patients report a beta-lactam allergy. Up to 90% of these
patients can tolerate penicillin and have been designated penicillin allergic
unnecessarily. Patients allergic to cephalosporins will have a cross-reaction to
penicillins 3% to 5% of the time. Overall, patients with a history of penicillin
allergy can tolerate cephalosporins although there are rare reports to severe,
sometimes fatal anaphylactic reactions. Neither penicillin- or cephalosporin-
allergic patients will react to aztreonam. The degree of cross-reactivity of
penicillins and cephalosporins with carbapenems appears to be low.
If a patient has had an immediate reaction to a drug in the past, an allergy
specialist should evaluate the patient before a drug of the same class is
administered to the patient. Patients with delayed onset reactions causing
fever, systemic symptoms or mucosal involvement should also be evaluated by an
allergy specialist before a drug of the same class is administered.
A patient with previous Type I reaction to a beta-lactam can be desensitized and
then receive therapeutic doses of the same class within a day. Severe
reactions during desensitization are uncommon. Pharmacy service must be
contacted for assistance and drug preparation. Infectious Disease consultation

Contents.Text: Link to Shigella/Enteroinvasive E. coli menu
Enteroaggretive E. coli (EAEC), Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC), and
EAEC infection can cause watery diarrhea with mucus that is occasionally bloody.
It is more common in patients with HIV and those who have traveled to developing
regions. EPEC infection is associated with severe acute watery diarrhea that is
occasionally bloody. ETEC infection causes acute watery diarrhea that is
occasionally severe. It is most common in travelers to tropical regions who are
exposed to contaminated food and water.
Antibiotic therapy is not required for mild to moderate disease caused by these
organisms because diarrhea often resolves on its own. Do not use antimotility
agents in patients with bloody stool.
Antimicrobial treatment in patients with HIV
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) and Shiga Toxin-producing E. coli (STEC)
EHEC and STEC disease often presents as bloody diarrhea. It is more common in
people who have consumed undercooked meats or poultry, fruits or unpasteurized
fruit juices, vegetables, leafy greens or seed sprouts. Exposure risks include
swimming in or drinking untreated fresh water and visiting a farm, petting zoo,
healthcare facility, prison or childcare facility.
Treatment includes supportive measures such as volume repletion and
administering appropriate nutrition. Do not use antimotility or antimicrobial
agents as they can increase shiga-toxin release and increase the risk of
EIEC disease typically presents as watery diarrhea, sometimes progressing to
bloody diarrhea. Refer to Shigella/Enteroinvasive E. coli menu for

4) References. At the bottom on each advice menu. These are key references for

If none of the recommended or alternative drugs is suitable you can find more

Antibiotic prophylaxis in dermatologic surgery remains an area of
uncertainty due to a paucity of data. Large, randomized, controlled trials
delineating the risk of surgical site infection, hematogenous total joint
infection, or infective endocardits following dermatologic surgery do not exist.

ENTERIC FEVER (INCLUDING TYPHOID AND PARATYPHOID FEVER)
Enteric fever is a systemic febrile illness caused by Salmonella enterica
serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A, B, or C. It is characterized by dramatic fever
and abdominal pain. Enteric fever typically occurs in patients who have traveled
to impoverished areas where the organisms are endemic, but can also be acquired
within the United States. Treatment is based on location of acquisition due to
increasing rates of fluoroquinolone resistance in Asia.

Epididymitis is inflammation of the epididymis and when testicles are involved
is referred to as epididymo-orchitis. Acute epididymitis is the most common
cause of scrotal pain in adults. Other features include scrotal erythema and
edema, pyuria, dysuria, thickened epididymis, swollen testis, and is usually
unilateral. It is primarily caused by infection but can also result from trauma
and autoimmune diseases. Testicular torsion should be ruled out before
treatment. Most cases in men aged 35 and older, those with recent urinary tract
instrumentation or surgery (e.g., prostate biopsy, vasectomy) are associated
with enteric Gram-negative rods. Most cases in men under age 35 are associated
with N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis. Resistant organisms are more likely if
the patient has been in the hospital for more than 48 hours or received a course
of antibiotics. There is increasing resistance in urinary pathogens to
A urine analysis, urine culture and urine nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)
should be performed in all cases of suspected epididymitis before starting
Patients at risk of sexually transmitted infections should be assessed for
treatment. Refer to the Urogenital section of the Antimicrobial CDSS for more
Patients with bacterial epididymitis treated with antibiotics should improve
within two or three days. If no improvement is noted, other causes of scrotal
pain and referral to a urologist should be considered.
Management should include bed rest, analgesics, and scrotal elevation. Older men
should have their residual urinary volume checked. If the residual volume is
elevated, the patient should be seen by a urologist as epididymitis is unlikely
to respond if the prostate is blocking the vas deferens.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX ESBL

Contents.Text: EXTENDED-SPECTRUM BETA-LACTAMASES, AMPC BETA-LACTAMASES, AND CARBAPENEMASES
In some Enterobacteriaceae and other Gram-negative bacilli, potent bacterial
enzymes have emerged that inactive many newer broad-spectrum beta lactam drugs.
These include extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs), AmpC beta-lactamases,
and carbapenemases. These enzymes are most common in strains of Escherichia
coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Acinetobacter, Salmonella, and Enterobacter. The
enzymes can be latent under many circumstances. However, in patients receiving
beta lactam antibiotics, the enzymes can be expressed and contribute to
treatment failure. Because of this, and since the enzymes continue to evolve,
they are difficult to detect in clinical microbiology laboratories. Bacteria
carrying these enzymes are often also resistant to many other commonly used
aminoglycosides, and others, through different mechanisms.
The St Cloud VA and the Minneapolis Microbiology Laboratories screen for
these enzymes, but no screening method is 100% sensitive.
If a patient is suspected of having a Gram-negative infection and is likely to
be colonized with bacteria carrying ESBLs, AmpC beta-lactamases, or
carbapenemases, empirical therapy with alternative drugs that are not
inactivated by these enzymes should be considered. Typical alternatives are
ESBLs inactivate most cephalosporins, monobactams, and peneicillins.
Alternatives include carbapenems, aminoglycosides, quinolones (although co-
resistence is common), cefepime, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and colistin.
AmpC beta-lactamases inactivate many cephalosporins, most penicillins, and beta
lactam-beta lactam inhibitor combinations. Alternatives include cefepime,
carbapenems, aminoglycosides, quinolones (although co-resistence is common),
Carbapenemases inactivate carbapenems. Most strains are also resistant to most
other antibiotic classes. Alternatives include aminoglycosides and colistin.
Risk factors for colonization or infection with ESBL, Amp-C beta-lactamase or
Central venous catheters and other indwelling tubes and drains
The Microbiology Laboratory report will indicate when one of these enzymes has
been detected. Clinicians must be aware that these enzymes may not be detected
in all strains that carry them. If a Gram-negative infection is not responding
to therapy with a beta-lactam drug, consider adding or switching to a drug that
is not a beta lactam and appears active in the susceptibility report.
These new enzymes have made therapy of enterobacteriaceae infections
more complicated and difficult. Please contact or consult the Infectious
Disease service with questions or for assistance.

common in strains of Acinetobacter, Citrobacter, Enterobacter, Escherichia coli,
Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Salmonella, and Serratia
marcescens. The enzymes can be latent under many circumstances. However, in
patients receiving beta lactam antibiotics, the enzymes can be expressed and
contribute to treatment failure. Because of this, and since the enzymes continue
to evolve, they are difficult to detect in clinical microbiology laboratories.
Bacteria carrying these enzymes are often also resistant to many other commonly
used antimicrobials, including trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones, and
others, through different mechanisms. Enterobacteriaceae, Pseudomonas and
Acinetobacter are increasingly resistant to all antimicrobials.
Clinicians must be aware that these enzymes may not be detected in all strains
that carry them. If a Gram-negative infection is not responding to therapy with
a beta lactam drug, consider adding or switching to a drug that is not a beta
lactam and appears active in the susceptibility report.

Contents.Text: Esophagitis is usually associated with non-infectious diseases like
gastroesophageal reflux disease, mucositis and pill-induced esophagitis.
Esophageal infection occurs primarily in immunosuppressed individuals (e.g.
chemotherapy, transplantation, HIV) and rarely in healthy individuals. The
majority of infectious esophagitis is caused by Candida albicans,
cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus. Aphthous ulceration of the
esophagus is common in HIV infection.

DIARRHEA WITH GIARDIA DUODENALIS (ALSO KNOWN AS G. LAMBLIA AND G.INTESTINALIS)
Illness with Giardia is typically subacute but varies widely in its time course.
Treatment is necessary when the patient has symptomatic disease. Diarrhea,
abdominal pain, bloating, belching, flatus, nausea, and vomiting are present
acutely and after several days give way to flatus, loose stools, belching, and
Asymptomatic carriage of Giardia is common in household contacts of people who
are infected with Giardia. Treatment of asymptomatic patients can be considered
if they have contact with immunocompromised or pregnant people or live or work
in settings where there is risk of spreading infection to others (e.g., food
Sanford keyword: Giardia duodenalis (G. intestinalis, G. lamblia)

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Ip)
Most acute disease is self-limited, and the virus does not cause chronic
disease. No specific antiviral therapy is available.
Patients who appear to be developing fulminant hepatitis, including those with
mental status changes should receive supportive treatment. Fulminant hepatitis
is suggested by increased prothrombin time, cholestasis, ascites, decreased
liver size, or decreasing serum albumin. Supportive treatment includes
maintenance of fluid and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction
of coagulation defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition
Prevention for persons with continuing high risk of disease
Vaccine should be offered to persons at high risk of hepatitis A infection: men
who have sex with men, travelers to endemic areas likely to be exposed, illegal
drug users, persons at occupational risk of disease, persons with chronic liver
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months
Prevention for persons with a specific, defined exposure
Post-exposure prophylaxis should be offered to persons with substantial exposure
to hepatitis A. Specifically, persons exposed to acute hepatitis through
household or sexual contact, persons who attend or work in a day care center
with a recent case, or employee or patron of a restaurant with a food handler
with hepatitis. Post exposure prophylaxis must be given within 2 weeks of
exposure. Vaccine can be given at the same time as immune-globulin.
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months
Sanford keyword: Hepatitis A, Acute, Treatment

decreasing serum albumin. Supportive treatment includes maintenance of fluid
and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction of coagulation
defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition with a low-
protein diet. Antiviral therapy is not indicated. Gastroenterology consult
Antiviral therapy for chronic hepatitis B is a complicated, highly specialized

Ocular herpes infection can be caused by either HSV-1 or HSV-2. The majority of
cases are caused by HSV-1. The recurrence rate of ocular herpes is 40% over a 5
year period, less than that of oral or genital herpes. Ocular herpes is a
major cause of blindness and typically presents as infection of the epithelium
of the cornea but can also rarely involve the stroma and endothelium.
Involvement of the stroma or endothelium requires treatment with topical
steroid and close monitoring. For these cases, start oral antiviral and consult
Antiviral prophylaxis is recommended for patients with multiple recurrences,
recurrent episodes with ulceration, recurrent inflammation with
scar/vascularization approaching visual axis, patients who have had keratoplasty
for HSV-related scarring/astigmatism, and patients who have had HSV keratitis
while on immunosuppressive therapy. Post-surgical prophylaxis is not discussed
here. Please consult ophthalmology for more information.

Contents.Text: HSV infection of the esophagus usually occurs in patients who are
immunocompromised, typically solid organ and bone marrow transplant
recipients.  In healthy patients HSV esophagitis occurs occasionally,
usually in men under the age of 40.
Patients usually present with odynophagia and dysphagia.  Fever
epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and heartburn are less frequent.
Some patients may have coexistent herpes labialis or oropharyngeal
ulcers.  Diagnosis is usually established with an upper endoscopy.
Suggestive findings may also be seen during a barium swallow.
Spontaneous resolution usually occurs in immunocompetent patients after
one to two weeks. Patients may respond more quickly if treated with a
Treatment for mild to moderate disease

Contents.Text: HOW TO FIND AN ALTERNATIVE ANTIMICROBIAL WITHIN THE CDSS
The CDSS has been developed locally with input from a broad, representative
group of clinicians. All antimicrobial recommendations within the Antimicrobial
CDSS are reviewed by a clinical pharmacist and an Infectious Diseases Medical
Specialist. Recommendations provided are based on local susceptibility patterns,
clinical evidence, local preferences, and national guidelines. In rare cases,
the recommended antimicrobials and listed alternatives may not be preferred for
the patient you are treating (e.g. isolate resistance, allergies, etc.). In
these cases, a broader set of alternative antimicrobials may be ordered through
the Antimicrobial CDSS. Like other antimicrobial orders in the CDSS,
antimicrobials ordered through the Alternative Antimicrobials menu do on require
a prior authorization or ID approval.
To access the Alternative Antimicrobials menu, navigate to the menu containing
antimicrobial recommendations for the infectious disease you are treating. At
the top of the menu, select the option Need an alternative antimicrobial
(typically item #6). Select the reason an alternative antimicrobial is required,
then the Alternative Antimicrobials menu will pop up.
The Alternative Antimicrobial menu contains antimicrobial regimens that have
been deemed appropriate for use as alternatives to recommended antimicrobials by
the Antimicrobial P&T Subcommittee. If the list does not contain the preferred
antimicrobial, contact or consult Infectious Diseases.
The regimens provided in the Alternative Antimicrobial menu are not tailored for
a specific infectious disease. The dose, frequency, and duration must be changed
based on the infectious disease you are treating as well as for patient specific
factors. The usage of alternative antimicrobials are monitored by the
Antimicrobial CDSS team for appropriateness and to identify infectious diseases

Contents.Text: How to find an alternative antimicrobial within the CDSS
The CDSS has been designed to offer antimicrobial prescribing advice quickly and
efficiently. Since inpatient and outpatient drugs are ordered differently, the
CDSS has both and inpatient and outpatient versions for prescribing.
The Antimicrobial CDSS is located within CPRS. When CPRS is open, click on the
Orders tab at the bottom left hand side of the CPRS window.
On the left-hand side of the Orders tab, click on the Medicine Inpt Orders.
On the left-hand side of the Orders tab, click on the Medicine Outpt Orders.
The main menu of the Antimicrobial CDSS contains links to categories of
infectious diseases based on syndrome/organ system (e.g. cardiovascular,
genitourinary, etc.), organisms (e.g. gram-positive bacteria, gram-negative
bacteria, viruses, etc.) and other special cases. To navigate to specific
infectious disease, select the category the infectious disease is associated
with. Within the category menu, select the specific infectious disease sub-menu
for recommendations, quick orders and pertinent resources (e.g., section-
specific consults, important drug properties, CDSS system help resources, etc.).
The Index is in the main menu at the top of the left-hand column under the
header Index of Antimicrobial CDSS content. The Index contains an alphabetized
list of Antimicrobial CDSS content. Find the infectious disease, organism or
other topic you are looking for by scrolling down the list. When you locate the
term you are looking for, click on it to be linked to the menu containing
specific recommendations, quick orders and pertinent resources.
Quick orders are preprogrammed with the usually recommended antimicrobial dose,
frequency and solution for the specific infectious disease.
Quick orders are not tailored to specific patient factors such as renal
insufficiency, comorbidities, contraindications, weight, allergies, etc. The
provider must assess every patient closely for these factors and modify
recommended antimicrobials if needed. To assist the provider, additional drug
information is provided within specific infectious diseases recommendation menus
and a link to more in depth information is provided at the top of these menus.
Alternatives to preferred antimicrobials quick orders are often provided in
recommendations, a broader selection of alternative antimicrobials is provided

Contents.Text: Acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q8h ($$) [R,DI] for 14 to 20 days
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 is the leading cause of sporadic fatal
encephalitis worldwide and should be suspected in patients who have symptoms
unexplained by other causes. Typical symptoms include acute alteration of
consciousness for more than 24 hours, fever, new onset seizures and/or focal
neurologic deficits. Patients taking natalizumab are at increased risk of HSV
encephalitis. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to achieve resolution
of infection and symptoms. If diagnosis is not certain and there is little
likelihood of herniation, obtain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample for HSV
polymerase chain reaction (PCR). MRI without contrast nearly always show
abnormal signs in patients with HSV encephalitis. Neurology and Infectious
Treatment, Initiate Immediately When HSV Encephalitis is Suspected

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration advised that the serious
side effects associated with fluoroquinolone antibacterial drugs
generally outweigh the benefits for patients with acute sinusitis, acute
bronchitis, and uncomplicated urinary tract infections who have other
treatment options. For patients with these conditions, fluoroquinolones should
be reserved for those who do not have alternative treatment options.
An FDA safety review has shown that fluoroquinolones when used systemically
are associated with disabling and potentially permanent serious side effects
that can occur together. These side effects can involve the tendons,
muscles, joints, nerves, and central nervous system.
FDA identified cases of hypoglycemic coma, resulting in death in some
instances. Most pateints had risk factors for hypoglycemia such as older age,
diabetes, renal insufficiency, and concomitant use of hypoglycemic drugs,
especally sulfonylureas.  FDA also identified reports of additional mental
health side effects, and requires that all fluoroquinolones include six
psychiatric adverse reactions (disturbance in attention, memory impairment,
stimulation, rare seizures, rare QT interval prolongation, and

"azole" antifungal agents, HIV protease inhibitors, and some anti-arrhythmic

Up-to-date, or a pharmacist for more information.
